title: 🧨 I wasn’t born with guilt — it was given to me
author: Unknown
content_html:
They didn’t call it guilt.

They called it being rude
...laz
content_text: They didn’t call it guilt. They called it being rude ...lazy ...too sensitive ...too emotional ...too quiet ...too much. So I started believing I was all of that — and worse. And somewhere between my first meltdown and my last missed deadline... guilt became my second language. Let me tell you something that wrecked me: I thought guilt was me . But it wasn’t. It was handed to me in small doses — every time I forgot someone’s birthday, every time I spaced out mid-conversation, every time I couldn’t do “simple” things like fill out a form or return a damn text. It started early. As a kid I got in trouble for daydreaming too much. As a teen I got mocked for being awkward. As an adult I got called selfish because I needed recovery, quiet, or space. So I did what a lot of us do. I blamed myself. I didn’t know my brain was wired differently. I didn’t know I was autistic. Or that I had ADHD. I just thought I was broken. Shame lives in silence. And I was silent for years. Even after getting sober. Even after getting diagnosed. I still caught myself apologizing for things that weren’t wrong — just different . I still shrank when people told me “you’re too intense” or “you should’ve known better.” And here’s the messed up part... Some of that shame was comforting. Because it gave me a script. It gave me something to hold onto in a world where I felt like a glitch in the system. But now? I’m uninstalling it. One line of code at a time. These days when guilt shows up — I ask it where it came from. Is this guilt mine? Or was it handed to me by a world that never took time to understand me? Was I really being rude? Or was I out of spoons, frozen, or just dissociating again? Was I selfish? Or was I protecting myself in the only way I knew how? Here’s what’s wild... The more I question the guilt The more it crumbles. Turns out shame doesn’t survive curiosity. I still feel it. God, I still feel it. Like when I cancel plans last minute Or when I forget to follow up Or when I miss another email that sat unopened for weeks. But now I don’t let it define me. Now I name it. I call it what it is: a side effect of surviving without support . And then I move on. Because I wasn’t born with guilt. It was given to me. And every day... I give it back. Final takeaway: If you feel guilt for just existing in your own brain — maybe it’s not guilt you created. Maybe it was installed. You can uninstall it too. Slowly. Gently. One broken belief at a time. So yeah... I wasn’t born with guilt — it was given to me. And I’m finally giving it back. Call to action: If this hit home, reply or leave a comment.
